title: How many months are in one school year? - Quora

response.answer_text: In most states, the school year is about 176–185 days of a certain number of hours/minutes in instruction per day. There are places where the number of days can be as high as around 200. Most places, there a certain number of work days that are non-instructional for teachers,and a number of days for “in-service” training (usually 18 to 24 hours). These days are pretty much paid work days, while years ago, many were not.. Some school systems will be able to devote more days to any of these by being more financially advantaged, and willing to pay for more student days ,“non-instructional” or training days. What is “required” from a state department of education/or instruction is always the minimum, meaning they can always exceed whatever—days in school, training or teacher work days. There is no requirement as to when these 176…. days are. This is up to what each system wants to when the school days are. This is found in that system’s “school calendar.” This allows for a school system to set the calendar to fit the needs and situation of their setting. Some school systems might have schools on a variety of actual schedule (such as a few schools that are year-round. These schools have long breaks, but are usually on a schedule that is different from the rest of the schools in the system.) In US school’s history, dates/days at school were originally very arranged on when students were needed on the farm. Also, school staff’s were related to and needed for the farms work also. So early on, schools in the country would take long breaks for planting in the spring and in the fall for harvest. The summer break was pretty short, but the fact that most schools did not have air conditioning, nor did the homes, the school times were more along the lines of early morning only till it was cooler. I know of schools in mountainous areas today that start pretty much in late summer, because they know there will be many days in the winter when transporting students or having teachers on the roads is not safe. When days are missed, the school systems usually has to add days to meet the minimum number of days. I live on the Gulf Coast, and families here want to start going to the beach pretty early in May. So here, school is out well before Memorial day, even if students have to go back to school in early August. Most school systems today, do all kinds of research on community work and vacation patterns, weather patterns and predictions, putting lots of work on the calendar, which is finally approved by the school boards. I taught at a school system where they started having two days “off” because of events in the community because the teachers would be out and there was not enough substitute teachers. Two more school systems I know, there are community events that leave no parking for teachers, and the buses can not get to the schools. (Not enough police to be involved with traffic for the event, and to police school parking lots, and schools that have to also use street parking of a daily basis. I grew up in Mobile, AL where the schools, as well at the schools in South LA,?New Orleans were always out for Madi Gras.

Traditionally, starting back when the United States was a country of agricultural families, children had the summer off to help work on the farm. Even when the culture shifted away from family farms, most families scheduled their vacations in the summer (ironically, to get away from the *city* heat). Summer was a full three months, June, July, and August. Traditionally (again), school started right after Labor Day (early September) in the U.S. and ran through Memorial Day (the very end of May) or a few days beyond. Thus the “school year” was nine months, even though those nine months included a Christmas or year-end break of almost two weeks and an Easter or spring break of a week. Nine months is 39 weeks, so that left 36 weeks or 180 (Monday through Friday) instructional days. In more recent decades the school year has encroached back into August and crept forward, nibbling away at June. Now it's almost ten months, first day to last. Still, there are expected to be the same old 180 classroom days. Note that any missed days during the year will probably require extending the school year further into June. Days are missed due to extreme weather and teachers' strikes, and for extraordinary events such as fires in the building, required health code cleanups, vermin infestation extermination, or widespread community illness outbreaks such as the flu. A few days off are frequently built into the schedule for teacher institutes (or ongoing education) as well as such holidays as Thanksgiving and Washington's Birthday (colloquially called Presidents Day). Still, the answer, one way or another, is typically 180 days for students, another +/- 5 for teachers.

Which country? Children are in school anywhere from 6 to 12 months, depending on where you live. Some countries only have a 6-month period due to how long the school day is. Schooling only lasting 6 months means they often start at 7 or 8 AM but are in school until 6 or 8 PM (10–12 hour days), most only go from 8 AM to 2 PM (a 6-hour day), Some go “half days” (which last anywhere from 2 to 4 hours). In some countries (and, yes, even a few districts in the U.S.A.) school is year round. Not that kids are in school every day of the month, all year…but, rather, for winter break, most kids get 2–3 weeks off - in a year round school they get a full month to a month and a half off. In most U.S. schools, “Spring Break” is a week, in a year-round school, it’s 2–3 weeks. Etc. So, while they do have to be in classrooms during the summer, they get longer breaks than those who school for 9–10 months. Even the ages are different. In some countries, kids start school at 3 years of age (average in the U.S.A. is 5) while in other countries, they don’t start until they’re at least 7. In some countries, kids go to school until they’re 18 and/or graduate. Some schools stop when kids are 16/graduate…and in some countries, children only go to school until they’re 13 or 14/graduate. Usually, the younger they are when they start school, the younger they are when they graduate, but that isn’t always the case, either. So…in order to be specific…what country are you in/asking about?

There are 180 days in one school year in the district i go to middle school in. Most months of the year have 30–31 days ( excluding my birthday month February) . Dividing 180 by 30 it would be roughly 6 months or more . School starts in August and ends in May. Counting all the months that would be about 10 months . So a school year is between 6–10 months. This is inconclusive because of so many more technicalities such as winter break , spring break , fall break, student holidays , February depending on the year , and inclement weather days. I’m not going to narrow it down because I don’t want plus we have a good range of how long a school year is, for me . but that’s all you wanted to know so That’s all i got See ya.

Seeing as some schools go from September to December (heck, even August through December) and then January to June, so you would be adding three to four months plus another six months, you would have either nine or ten months in one year. And yes, that includes some holidays like Halloween, Thanksgiving, Veteran’s Day, Columbus Day as well as Rosh Shanah and Yom Kippur (excluding summer and winter breaks, as that would be about three weeks of a break in winter, and about a two month break in summer).

There are 180 days in a school year. This equates to 36 weeks and about 6 months. So students are in school for almost exactly half the year. Where I go to school, the school year is from the last week of August to the 1st/2nd week of June. This will of course vary based on school type (private&charter vs public), country, and hemisphere. For example, in Brazil, since the seasons are opposite of those in the northern hemisphere, school begins in their fall (but spring for us). But in the US, it’s typically from August/September through May/June.

It depends upon where you are. In some states in the USA, the school year runs traditionally from the Tuesday after Labor Day in early September to some time in June. In many communities, school is usually over by the third week of June. In New York City, however, the school year for teachers begins before Labor Day and ends June 28.

I don’t think that it is how many months in a school year but rather how many weeks are in a school year. Usually, a school semester in high school is 18 weeks so there are 36 weeks in a general school year. Of course, you have to count in holidays, a week of Easter and 2 weeks of Christmas vacation. Add the rest and that is the break during summer unless you have to attend summer school. Basically, that's it.

It depends on the country, how long their breaks during school time last and of course, when school starts and ends. Here in Romania, it’s usually 36 weeks, but for kindergarten and elementary school, it is 35 weeks due to the break they have between the end of the October and the beginning of November. We end school around the start of June, usually after 2–3 weeks into June. 8th graders (the ones who are graduating middle school with a high school enterance exam) end school a week earlier and 12th graders (the ones who are graduating high school with an university enterance exam) end school about two weeks earlier.

In the state of Georgia, students attend school for 180 days. Since a month is usually counted as 20 school days, there are nine months in a school year. However, the time frame for most school systems is 10 months due to holidays that are scheduled throughout the year, and, of course, this varies with each school system.

Not sure how other countries time their school year out, but in the US, the standard is about 9 months. I got this because the first semester is August 20 through December 20. is about 4 months. Then you have January through middle to end of May, which is 5 months. So, I would say a good estimate would be 9 months. Typically, students have June, July, and most of August off. I hope this answer helps. Thanks for your question!

Typical US school year runs August to December then January to May. Each school year has 2 semesters and 4 9week periods or terms or quarters. There are 2 9week periods in each semester. Overall that’s roughly 10 months.

In the US there are usually 180–190 school days per year covering 10 months. This can differ from state to state. In Kentucky the school year was reduced by approximately 3 months because school was closed for snow days in the late 70’s.

This may vary depending on the country or state, but in Australia, schools commence at the start of February (or the last couple of days of January) and end mid to late December. So, not including the 2 week holidays in between terms (there are 4 terms), school goes for about 11 months.

I had to sit down and think about this: (Sometimes) part of August September-December (4) January-May (5) (Sometimes) part of June Approximately nine months, but less if excluding winter and spring breaks and holidays.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Jaden Yenjai and Andy Zerhusen

response.answer_text: Most states require the school year to be a certain number of days or minutes in order to count. In Texas it use be be 180 days is equal to a school year, but changes in state law has redefined a school year as 75,600 minutes and a school day is 420 minutes. This was done to give school districts more flexibility in making up missed school days.

By State law, most schools run for 180 days. These 180 days generally run within the months of August thru May, sometimes parts of June. Some schools as in my local school district will be doing all year. Just means 180 days spread out over 12 months.

11 if you talking calendar months because you go to school in every month except for August in UK but if you are talking as in the 39 week school year then it is 8.975 months of you just mean time at school on its own.
9 months too many August, September, October, December, January, February, March, April, May for me. Excluding snowdays, breaks and teacher development days that's about 8 months.

In the US school years generally start in September and end in either May or June of the following year. University school years generally end in May, making it 8 months. Elementary and high school years generally end in June, making it nine months.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Tannaz Adib and Andy Zerhusen

response.answer_text: It's usually 180 days of school. If you take 30 days in most months, teacher work days, holidays and breaks (winter break and sprinf break) most of time it's 9-10 months in a school year
In Florida, we start school in the beginning of August and end at the end of May. For students, there are 180 school days, us teachers are scheduled to work 196.

Generally, high school lasts from the end of August (or perhaps beginning of September) to the beginning/middle of June. Not including time off for winter break and the like, generally a school year lasts around nine months.
In my district, students start school in August (August 19 this school year) and end in June (June 5, 2020) there are 37 weeks or 180 days.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Lana Saint Clair

response.answer_text: States may vary, but in CA most schools require a minimum of 180 days of instruction. they also define the duty hrs for an instructional “day.” usually around seven hrs.

The length of a school year varies from country to country and Educational school district. Check with your school district to discover how many days your school year entails. Ontario Canada has 194 instructional days. Instructional days also includes days used to implement exams. Other provinces have different instructional school days.
In Canada, there are 9 months of school for primary and junior secondary students. High school students have various schedules.
A2A School is usually nine months September to June in the U.S. There are some experimental situations where children go to school all year and have 3 weeks off every four months.
For regular school in the U.S we have 9 months of school and 3 months break. Keep in mind that some schools go all year round.
August through June is 11 months. A few of those months students aren’t in class for the complete 30 day period, but students attend in 11 months out of the year in many states.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Monica Ribourg and Jaden Yenjai

response.answer_text: Generally 10, September to June. Elementary and High School. Post secondary is less.
There is no correct answer(In the USA).Each school district sets their own schedule.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Brandon C. Njichop

response.answer_text: 9 months, I think✌
69 that’s how it works
9 1/2 months — 10 months
10 Months.
8 months
